content: I'm drafting a FHIRcast conformance / discoverability feature, and just largely copying SMART's. Why did we move away from /metadata, again? It just introduces another url, but is still dependent upon knowing where the FHIR server is. Was the primary justification that /metadata is just getting too darn big/slow?
I think well known is also an openId Connect feature, and many of the features we're advertising are defined in that standard
I believe the openId connect .well-known is under the server root, so most likely in a different place than the FHIR one
we moved into an external file to have a place where we could more easily and idiomatically express things like smart capabilities.

the ballot process last time around introduced a whole new set of questions and expectations about discoverable metadata, and trying to cram this into the capability statement for the whole server felt like it would be a difficult game.

maybe with some of the proposed changes to the way capability statement works, this is something that we could reevaluate. But these haven't landed in a meaningful way yet; I have to say I do like the simplicity of a simple json file with well defined properties.

I do like the simplicity of a simple json file with well defined properties.

Are you saying you like .well-known better?
One consideration was also data size. Clients need to download the whole conformance statement, easily over 1 MB, to discover 3 URLs.

Pascal Pfiffner said:

One consideration was also data size. Clients need to download the whole conformance statement, easily over 1 MB, to discover 3 URLs.

_elements didn't work?
_elements only applies at the top level :/

I have to say I do like the simplicity of a simple json file with well defined properties.

So, just to throw another consideration out there, I've got an implementation of SMART app launch that is essentially completely decoupled from the FHIR server. Being able to return the necessary SMART configuration from a URL other than the conformance statement makes this substantially simpler.
